posts.name: Greyson Parrelli
posts.cooked:
TL;DR You can test the new Signal Backups feature on Android on our staging servers. Grab the self-updating apk here!

Hello, everyone!

Many of you are aware that we’ve been working on a new end-to-end encrypted backup system for quite a while. Well, today, we’re finally ready to start testing it with external users

The new backup system fulfills so many of the things people have wanted for so long:

  • Hosted by Signal, so your data is safe even if you made a local backup but dropped your phone in a lake.
  • The ability to dynamically offload media so that Signal takes up less space on your phone, while still letting you download that media on the fly if you scroll back.
  • An independent backup format that is readable by all clients, so that you can do things like backup on Android and restore on iOS.
  • A generous optional free tier that will ensure that all of the text content of your messages is backed up, as well as the most recent 45 days of media.
  • A fairly-priced paid tier that allows us to offer 100GB of media storage in a way that is sustainable for us as an organization.

And of course these things are handled with the utmost care in traditional Signal fashion:

  • Backups are end-to-end encrypted with a strong key that only you have access to.
  • Backups are disabled by default.
  • Backups are structured so that the Signal service cannot associate a backup with a given user.
  • Payments are structured so that the Signal service cannot associate a payment with a given user.

Needless to say, this is a very large feature. It touches a lot of different pieces of the app, adds a lot of new screens, drastically changes the registration flow, and introduces scores of new edge cases and error flows. So, just like the username testing we did before launch, we’re putting a callout to forum users to test a staging build.

What is a “staging build”, you ask? To answer that, I’ll quote from the aforementioned username testing post:

Public Username Testing (Staging Environment)

Think of The Staging Environment as a parallel Signal universe: you’ll need to install and run a new build (links below), and register for a new account with a phone number (you can use the same one you’re using in Production). Anybody you wish to talk with in Staging needs to be registered in Staging as well (please coordinate with your Signal testing pals in group chats rather than posting your phone numbers and usernames to the forums). We have no uptime guarantees in Staging, and it’s likely that push notifications won’t work as well, or potentially at all, during your testing.

Once you’re registered on staging, you can go to Settings > Backups. There, you’ll see the new UI for configuring backups.

Notably, at the top of that screen, there is a fun “ALPHA ONLY” section that lets you forcibly set your backup tier to be “Unset”, “Free”, or “Paid”. “Unset” is the default, and it means that this override switch does nothing. Choosing “Free” or “Paid” will forcibly put you in one of those tiers, allowing you to test paid backups without having to actually spend money. Important to note, though: changing this toggle before you go through onboarding will cause you to skip onboarding, and you’ll need to go grab your backup key from the backup settings yourself. I recommend going through onboarding first for the Free tier, and then changing this to paid afterwards.

To use the “optimize storage” feature I alluded to earlier, where we’ll dynamically offload media to save space on-device, go to Settings > Data and storage > Manage storage > Optimize on-device storage.

Otherwise, we encourage you to explore the UI like you would any other app. In particular, this is the type of feedback we’d love to hear:

  • Is there anything that isn’t working correctly (i.e. are there bugs)?
  • Are any of the screens or in-app explanations confusing? Do you feel like things could be described better or more clearly?
  • Is something missing? Is there a feature or capability that you’d expect to be present that isn’t there?
  • Is anything weirdly slow or otherwise performing poorly?

While you’re testing, try to test different edge cases. Send media before a backup, during a backup, and after a backup. Try out different password managers. Reset the app and restore the backup before the old one finishes. This is a staging build, where you don’t have any data anyway, so we hope this encourages you to test the restore process. It is possible you may hit rate limits if you re-register a lot – if that happens, just wait 12-24 hours and try again

Right now, testing is only available on Android. Just like username testing, you can download a self-updating APK here. New builds will go out as we fix stuff!

FAQ

Backups cost money? How can I backup my data for free?
Local backups still exist, and they’re going to get much better! We have a rewrite of local backups that uses the new cross-platform backup format that’s almost complete. In addition to using the new cross-platform format, it’s also much smarter about only writing diffs for changed media. This means that creating new backups will be much quicker (seconds instead of minutes), and any external syncing tools you may have set up will be much faster. We’re planning to launch this shortly after the initial backup launch.

When is this coming to other platforms?
Soon™! The other teams are hard at work implementing these changes, but alpha testing like this is much more difficult on iOS due to platform restrictions. If you’d like to test something on iOS, you can always link an iPad – the code that imports your message history is largely the same code that restores a backup

What about disappearing messages? Do those get backed up?
We made the decision to exclude disappearing messages that have been read and are due to expire within 24 hours, or if the message timer is less than 24 hours, regardless of whether it was read or not. We chose not to exclude all disappearing messages because many people set 4 week timers on their chats for the purpose of tidiness, and we think it would be unpleasant to restore a backup just to discover that all of those messages are gone. We think this strikes a good middle ground, but we are interested in hearing your feedback during this testing period.

View-once messages are excluded from backups in all cases.

When is this going to beta/prod?
That depends a lot on what we discover during this initial testing phase! But it’ll be at least several weeks, and possibly longer if we discover any bugs that are particularly difficult to troubleshoot or fix.

posts.cooked:
greyson-signal:

Local backups still exist, and they’re going to get much better!

Wonderful news.

And I like the trademarked

greyson-signal:

Soon™

I don’t have multiple numbers to test something out, but here’s a question.

What happens if I unregister then reregister with a different number but using the same device without uninstalling the Signal client? Will the paid tier backup still be applied? Does it survive changing the number from within the client?

When repeating the backup code, the spacing made me think that I somehow entered an additional space:

Screenshot_20250625-205747257×428 8.04 KB

Also: the free tier says “Text + 30 days of media”, not 45

When I first set the ALPHA ONLY tag to ‘Free’, the Signal Backups said that my last backup was at 6:59 PM, but I had not yet taken a backup and the current time is was 3:00 PM.

I viewed the backup key (before taking any backups), and tried to Save to password manager. I initially got an error. When going back to the backup settings screen, it said that last backup was ‘now’, but I still had not taken any backups.

When trying to view the backup key, the dialog says “Unlock to view backup key”. After trying the Signal PIN which I just set, I then realized that it meant my phone’s screen unlock PIN. This dialog could be more descriptive.
Anyone, feel free to add me on the staging server with “username” Cue.01

posts.name: Greyson Parrelli
posts.cooked:
CueHD:

What happens if I unregister then reregister with a different number but using the same device without uninstalling the Signal client?

Backups are tied to your Account Identifier (ACI), meaning if you choose a different number during registration, you will not be able to restore a Signal Backup.

But if you change you number using Settings > Account > Change phone number, that works just fine. That flow changes the number associated with your ACI, so your backup is still linked.

FluffyPotato:

Also: the free tier says “Text + 30 days of media”, not 45

Ah, I believe that’s a remotely configured value, and it’s not correct on staging. I’ll look into it.

CueHD:

After trying the Signal PIN which I just set, I then realized that it meant my phone’s screen unlock PIN.

Yeah, we might be able to use the same prompts we use when accessing linked devices. We’ve heard confusion around that in the past.

CueHD:

When I first set the ALPHA ONLY tag to ‘Free’, the Signal Backups said that my last backup was at 6:59 PM, but I had not yet taken a backup and the current time is was 3:00 PM.

The “forced” backup tiers get a little funny because we implement them by mocking network responses, so some things get a little funky, apologies.

CueHD:

When going back to the backup settings screen, it said that last backup was ‘now’, but I still had not taken any backups.

This sounds more like a bug though

link_counts.title: Combining Android and iOS backups

posts.cooked: I noticed that media is not uploaded when clicking the backup now button. Presumably just the message with the download link is backed up? How does that work for the paid tier that the media file is not removed after 45 days?

posts.name: Greyson Parrelli
posts.cooked:
FluffyPotato:

I noticed that media is not uploaded when clicking the backup now button. Presumably just the message with the download link is backed up? How does that work for the paid tier that the media file is not removed after 45 days?

So for free tier, there’s no need to explicitly upload media, because we basically take advantage of the fact that attachments are downloadable for 45 days :) So really it’s like you’re downloading a normal attachment.

For the paid tier, after you’ve enabled backups, we proactively copy them into your backup as your send/receive them, so they’re typically already uploaded by the time you create a backup.

greyson-signal:

So for free tier, there’s no need to explicitly upload media, because we basically take advantage of the fact that attachments are downloadable for 45 days :

So for the free tier, if a restore occurs after the 45 day expiration, the media will not be restored. That should be better explained somewhere since I would expect that an actual backup would include the media.

I know I brought this up before, but now that the new backup system is mature enough for public testing, what’s the final decision for backing up the identity keys?

Is it like legacy backup where I’ll get back my keys when i restore, or will people start getting notifications for identity key changes when I restore a backup using the new system?

While it may not matter to the vast majority of Signal users, some users actually use and rely on verifying identity keys out-of-band. (e.g. some journalists, etc) plus it’s good practice anyway.

I tried to enable cloud backup and chose to save the restore passphrase in a passwordmanager, then i had to store in my google account, but i chose never, because i would like to store it in a local password manager. After that, if i choose to store it in a password manager, i get back to the settings screen. Once Signal crashed completely.

https://debuglogs.org/android/7.47.0-nightlyBackup-2025-06-25-18-07-32/1572e3965aea02653e0783df361399f01b63d416b2ab9127ae5160941b0ae4c9

posts.name: Greyson Parrelli
posts.cooked:
tony10:

what’s the final decision for backing up the identity keys?

We decided to not store the identity keys in backups.

However, you may notice that on the welcome screen when you first install the app, you can indicate that you have your old device. If you go through that flow, you’ll be prompted to scan a QR code from the old device, and if you do so, we will transfer the identity keys that way.

greyson-signal:

We decided to not store the identity keys in backups.

Will local backups stop including identity keys as well (i’m in favor of that)?

greyson-signal:

We decided to not store the identity keys in backups.

Can you share why?

greyson-signal:

If you go through that flow, you’ll be prompted to scan a QR code from the old device, and if you do so, we will transfer the identity keys that way.

I actually thought all of the device transfer/backup systems will use the new unified protos so that we can transfer/restore cross platform, does that mean that the device transfer will not benefit from the new system and will stick to platform dependent formats?

posts.name: Greyson Parrelli
posts.cooked:
QuickBanana:

Will local backups stop including identity keys as well (i’m in favor of that)?

The new local backups will not include the identity keys either (the existing format will remain unchanged, and we’ll read it for a very long time, but eventually we’ll stop writing it).

tony10:

Can you share why?

It’s just the most sensitive thing we could possibly store, and we’re not quite ready to make the jump

tony10:

I actually thought all of the device transfer/backup systems will use the new unified protos so that we can transfer/restore cross platform, does that mean that the device transfer will not benefit from the new system and will stick to platform dependent formats?

So right now the device transfer process is unchanged from what it was before. The QR scanning I mentioned earlier is a separate thing that will let you do a backup restore much more quickly by sharing the backup key + identity keys over an ephemeral encrypted websocket that’s established via the QR code (basically the same thing we do for linking a new device).

In terms of cross-platform device transfer, we have some ideas, but all of them are tricky or have trade-offs, because Apple has made it very difficult for Android + iOS devices to communicate directly :)

accepted_answer.name: link ✦
accepted_answer.excerpt:
closing this as backups on android are now available in the stable release (as a beta level feature)

(and coming soon to ios and desktop!)

for specific issues, questions, requests etc. please create individual topics

for general discussion about the feature, use:

  • Signal Blog: Introducing Signal Secure Backups
  • Encrypted cloud backups
